awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Optimized mm-Wave Transistors for 5G Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a transistor for better heat dissipation capability for high-frequency semiconductor devices.  In general, the demand for millimeter (mm)-wave transistors is steadily increasing.  In these devices, electromagnetic wave propagation effects and heat dissipation are among the most limiting factors for production. The proposed technologies in this project are applied to the design and fabrication of optimized mm-wave transistors.  These transistors demonstrate superior performance compared to currently available technologies. In addition, the devices have a smaller footprint compared to conventional transistors performing the same functionality. The new designs result in more devices per wafer, and each individual device may be capable of producing higher power and operating over a wider bandwidth. Such performance enhancements may allow savings in cost per component. Moreover, the new transistors may have characteristics enabling them to meet more stringent performance specifications. Subsequently, new systems with advanced functionalities may be designed that will open new market areas.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a fabrication technology that is applicable to high-frequency semiconductor devices. The proposed technology describes novel transistor electrode designs to match the phase velocity of the propagating waves on the input and output electrodes. This enables relaxation of the current limitations on the electrode width, which reduces the number of fingers needed to meet the desired device gain, output power, and other performance parameters. The competitive advantage of the proposed technology is to allow fabricating wider transistors, which provides more radio frequency power. The thermal management issues and their associated challenges in mm-wave transistors also are addressed in this project. The proposed technology modifies the substrates enabling them to act as better heat absorbers by enhancing their overall thermal conductance. The novelty in this technology is founded on improvements in thermal properties of the die to extract the heat generated at the surface and/or in the active layer at the junctions, offering enhanced capabilities for heat removal. Results from research on the analysis of the transistor performances demonstrate the promise of this technology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Throughout the life of the award of the National I-Corps program, the team demonstrated a great understanding of the market need and found the product-market fit for their proposed technology by identifying the value propositions and the benefits the industry sector gains with this innovation. Moreover, the team could identify the target industry segment and build a close relationship with the potential customers. Furthermore, the team could identify the players in the supply chain and distribution channels. Evaluating the business model canvas helped the team to visualize their path to market for launching a successful business. This program assisted the team to begin fabricating their innovative device and further validating their findings. Additionally, this program strengthened the ability of the team to move forward in the entrepreneurial route to successfully commercialize this product. Successfully completing the NSF I-Corps program put the team in a better position in developing a clear idea about the commercialization path and establishing a close relationship with potential partners.

The intellectual merit of the project resulted from 156 interviews conducted throughout the life of the award (both virtually and by attending multiple conferences in person) showed that the proposed innovative technology is ready to move beyond the fundamental research/discovery phase into a commercialized product. The engineers and engineering managers interviewed from different market segments such as aerospace, defense, and chip manufacturing companies, suggested that this product would help address several major pain points faced in their sector such as (1) inability to perform in harsh environments and higher temperatures; (2) inability to operate at higher speeds; (3) longer reworking cycles (4) higher cost of the final system (5) and market loss. The inability of devices to provide the desired performance in high-temperature gradients is often due to a possible lack of efficient cooling techniques for many high-power transistor devices. Exhaustive reworking cycles are also the result of using immature semiconductor materials in the device structure, which is the primary reason for the higher cost of the final systems. Additionally, another major pain point of the electronic chip manufacturers as the system integrators is the market loss due to not being able to satisfy the growing need of customers in fabricating devices with smaller sizes and dimensions without forfeiting other system specifications.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project was the development of solutions for high-speed and high-temperature operation of transistors, which enables the expansion of broadband services in rural and impoverished areas that are underserved. According to the literature review, conducted research, and the customer discovery findings during the I-Corps program and after, the team realized that their product with the proposed innovative enhancements would have a significant economic impact by saving a great amount of time, money, and resources for the electronic chip manufacturing companies. This is done by enabling current semiconductor materials to demonstrate improved performance when utilized in the structure of optimized transistors which results in enhanced, low-cost, and smaller systems. Moreover, throughout the life of the award and after, the team received entrepreneurial guidance from the commercialization expert who served as the Industry Mentor for the I-Corps program. Both the Technical Lead and Industry Mentor are from the underrepresented communities. As representatives of women active in entrepreneurship and leadership, TL?s eagerness to learn entrepreneurial skills and the IM?s knowledge can be transferred to the development of a more diversified workforce.

 


Last Modified: 05/25/2022
Modified by: Samir El-Ghazaly
